newsitem.title: INDIA: Shell unit to build 2 India LPG terminals.
newsitem.headline: Shell unit to build 2 India LPG terminals.

text.p: Bharat Shell Ltd, the Indian subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell, said on Monday it is building two liquified petroleum gas (LPG) import terminals.
The company said the southern Andhra Pradesh government approved its plan to build a marine platform and an LPG import terminal at the Kakinada port on the eastern coast.
The project is estimated to cost 1.2 billion rupees.

"To cater to the increasing demand for LPG in the country, Bharat Shell is also constructing an LPG import terminal at Pipavav in Gujarat at an anticipated cost of 480 million rupees," the firm said in a statement.
This would cater to the western and northern Indian markets.
Bharat Shell, a joint venture of Shell and Indian refiner Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd (BPCL) said it commissioned a 770 million rupee lubricant plant near Bombay.
The Shell Group and Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd plan to jointly build a $2.0 billion refinery in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, the statement said without giving any details.
